odl.operator package¶

Submodules¶

odl.operator.default module¶

Default operators defined on any space of a certain kind.

Class name Description
ScalingOperator SelfAdjointOperator scaling an element with a real number.
ZeroOperator ScalingOperator with scalar equal to 0
IdentityOperator ScalingOperator with scalar equal to 1
LinCombOperator LinearOperator mapping two space elements to the linear combination with two fixed scalars.
MultiplyOperator Operator of multiplying two space elements. The range needs to be an Algebra for the multiplication to be well-defined.
class odl.operator.default.IdentityOperator(space)[source]¶

Bases: odl.operator.default.ScalingOperator

Operator mapping each element to itself.

class odl.operator.default.LinCombOperator(space, a, b)[source]¶

Bases: odl.operator.operator._DefaultCallOperator, odl.operator.operator.LinearOperator

Operator mapping two space elements to a linear combination.

This opertor calculates:

outp = a*inp[0] + b*inp[1]

class odl.operator.default.MultiplyOperator(space)[source]¶

Bases: odl.operator.operator._DefaultCallOperator, odl.operator.operator.LinearOperator

Operator multiplying two elements.

The multiply operator calculates:

outp = inp[0] * inp[1]

This is only applicable in Algebras.

class odl.operator.default.ScalingOperator(space, scalar)[source]¶

Bases: odl.operator.operator.SelfAdjointOperator

Operator of multiplication with a scalar.

domain¶

Return the operator domain.

None

domain : LinearSpace
The domain of the operator
>>> from odl.space.cartesian import Rn
>>> r3 = Rn(3)
>>> op = ScalingOperator(r3, 2.0)
>>> op.domain
Rn(3)
inverse¶

Return the inverse operator.

None

inv : ScalingOperator
Scaling by 1/scale
>>> from odl.space.cartesian import Rn
>>> r3 = Rn(3)
>>> vec = r3.element([1, 2, 3])
>>> op = ScalingOperator(r3, 2.0)
>>> inv = op.inverse
>>> inv(op(vec)) == vec
True
>>> op(inv(vec)) == vec
True
range¶

Return the operator range.

None

domain : LinearSpace
The domain of the operator
>>> from odl.space.cartesian import Rn
>>> r3 = Rn(3)
>>> op = ScalingOperator(r3, 2.0)
>>> op.range
Rn(3)
class odl.operator.default.ZeroOperator(space)[source]¶

Bases: odl.operator.default.ScalingOperator

Operator mapping each element to the zero element.

odl.operator.operator module¶

Abstract mathematical (linear) operators.

Operators are in the most general sense mappings from one set (Set) to another. More common and useful are operators mapping a vector space (LinearSpace) into another. Many of those are linear, and as such, they have additional properties. See the class documentation for further details. In addition, this module defines classes for sums, compositions and further combinations of operators of operators.

Furthermore, there are two convenience functions for quick operator prototyping:

Name Return type Description
operator SimpleOperator (subclass of Operator) Create an Operator by specifying either a call or an apply method (or both) for evaluation. See the function doc for a full description.
linear_operator SimpleLinearOperator (subclass of LinearOperator) Create an Operator by specifying either a call or an apply method (or both) for evaluation as well domain and range. See the function doc for a full description.
class odl.operator.operator.LinearOperator[source]¶

Bases: odl.operator.operator.Operator

Abstract linear operators.

A LinearOperator is an Operator which satisfies the linearity relation

op(scalar * x + y) == scalar * op(x) + op(y)

for all scalars and all vectors x and y. A LinearOperator can only be defined if domain and range are both LinearSpace instances.

LinearOperator differs from Operator in the following ways

Attribute/Method (Return) type Description
adjoint (short: T) LinearOperator Additional attribute. Satisfies op.adjoint.domain == op.range, op.adjoint.range == op.domain and op.domain.inner(x, op.adjoint(y)) == op.range.inner(op(x), y).
derivative (point) LinearOperator op.derivative == op
__add__(other) depends If other is a LinearOperator the sum is a LinearOperatorSum
__add__(other) depends If other is a LinearOperator, the sum is a LinearOperatorSum
__mul__(other) depends If other is a scalar, the product is a LinearOperatorScalarMult
__rmul__ (other) depends If other is a scalar, the product is a LinearOperatorScalarMult

See Operator for a list of public attributes and methods as well as further help.

T¶

Shorthand for adjoint.

adjoint¶

The operator adjoint.

derivative(point)[source]¶

Return the operator derivative at ‘point’.

For a LinearOperator, this is equivalent to op(point), i.e. a linear operator is its own derivative.

class odl.operator.operator.LinearOperatorComp(left, right, tmp=None)[source]¶

Bases: odl.operator.operator.OperatorComp, odl.operator.operator.LinearOperator

Expression type for the composition of linear operators.

LinearOperatorComp(left, right) <==> (x –> left(right(x)))

The composition is only well-defined if left.domain == right.range.

See LinearOperator and Operator for a list of public attributes and methods as well as further help.

adjoint¶

The operator adjoint.

The adjoint of the operator composition is the composition of the operator adjoints in reverse order:

LinearOperatorComp(left, right).adjoint == `LinearOperatorComp(right.adjoint, left.adjoint)

class odl.operator.operator.LinearOperatorScalarMult(op, scalar)[source]¶

Bases: odl.operator.operator.OperatorLeftScalarMult, odl.operator.operator.LinearOperator

Expression type for the linear operator scalar multiplication.

LinearOperatorScalarMult(op, scalar) <==> (x –> scalar * op(x))

For linear operators, left and right scalar multiplications are equal.

See LinearOperator and Operator for a list of public attributes and methods as well as further help.

adjoint¶

The operator adjoint.

The adjoint of the operator scalar multiplication is the scalar multiplication of the operator adjoint:

LinearOperatorScalarMult(op, scalar).adjoint == `LinearOperatorScalarMult(op.adjoint, scalar)

class odl.operator.operator.LinearOperatorSum(op1, op2, tmp_ran=None, tmp_dom=None)[source]¶

Bases: odl.operator.operator.OperatorSum, odl.operator.operator.LinearOperator

Expression type for the sum of operators.

LinearOperatorSum(op1, op2) <==> (x –> op1(x) + op2(x))

See Operator for a list of public attributes and methods as well as further help.

adjoint¶

The operator adjoint.

The adjoint of the operator sum is the sum of the operator adjoints:

LinearOperatorSum(op1, op2).adjoint == `LinearOperatorSum(op1.adjoint, op2.adjoint)

class odl.operator.operator.Operator[source]¶

Bases: future.types.newobject.newobject

Abstract operator.

Operator is an abstract class, i.e. it can only be subclassed, not used directly.

Any subclass of `Operator` must have the following attributes:

domain : Set
The set of elements this operator can be applied to
range : Set
The set this operator maps to

In addition, any subclass needs to implement at least one of the methods `_call()` and `_apply()`. These are explained in the following.

Out-of-place evaluation means that the operator is applied, and the result is written to a new element which is returned. In this case, a subclass has to implement the method

_call(self, inp) <==> operator(inp)

Parameters:

inp : domain element
An object in the operator domain to which the operator is applied.

Returns:

outp : range element
An object in the operator range, the result of the operator evaluation.

In-place evaluation means that the operator is applied, and the result is written to an existing element provided as an additional argument. In this case, a subclass has to implement the method

_apply(self, inp, outp) <==> outp <– operator(inp)

Parameters:

inp : domain element
An object in the operator domain to which the operator is applied.
outp : range element
An object in the operator range to which the result of the operator evaluation is written.

Returns:

None

If not both _apply() and _call() are implemented and the range is a LinearSpace, a default implementation of the respective other is provided.

Name Type Description
domain Set Elements to which the operator can be applied
range Set Results of operator application are elements of this set.
inverse (short:I) Operator The inverse operator. Raises NotImplementedError by default.
Signature Return type Description
apply(inp, outp) None Apply the operator to inp and write to outp. In addition to the private method _apply(), error checks are performed.
__call__(inp) element of range Implements the call pattern op(inp). In addition to the private method _call(), error checks are performed.
derivative (point) LinearOperator The operator derivative at point. Raises NotImplementedError by default.
__add__(op2) OperatorSum |Implements op + op2.
__mul__ (other)
depends |Implements other * op. If
|other is a scalar, an |`OperatorLeftScalarMult is |created. If other is an |Operator, the result is an |OperatorPointwiseProduct.
__rmul__ (other)
depends |Implements op * other. If
|other is a scalar, an |`OperatorRightScalarMult is |created. If other is an |Operator, the result is an |OperatorPointwiseProduct.
I¶

Shorthand for inverse.

apply(inp, outp)[source]¶

op.apply(inp, outp) <==> outp <– op(inp).

Implementation of in-place operator evaluation with the private _apply() method and added error checking.

inp : element of self.domain
An object in the operator domain to which the operator is applied. The object is treated as immutable, hence it is not modified during evaluation.
outp : element of self.range
An object in the operator range to which the result of the operator evaluation is written. The result is independent of the initial state of this object.

None

>>> from odl.space.cartesian import Rn
>>> from odl.operator.default import IdentityOperator
>>> rn = Rn(3)
>>> op = IdentityOperator(rn)
>>> x = rn.element([1, 2, 3])
>>> y = rn.element()
>>> op.apply(x, y)
>>> y
Rn(3).element([1.0, 2.0, 3.0])
derivative(point)[source]¶

Return the operator derivative at point.

inverse¶

Return the operator inverse.

class odl.operator.operator.OperatorComp(left, right, tmp=None)[source]¶

Bases: odl.operator.operator.Operator

Expression type for the composition of operators.

OperatorComp(left, right) <==> (x –> left(right(x)))

The composition is only well-defined if left.domain == right.range.

See Operator for a list of public attributes and methods.

derivative(point)[source]¶

Return the operator derivative.

The derivative of the operator composition follows the chain rule:

OperatorComp(left, right).derivative(point) == LinearOperatorComp(left.derivative(right(point)), right.derivative(point))

domain¶

The operator domain.

Corresponds to right.domain

inverse¶

The operator inverse.

The inverse of the operator composition is the composition of the inverses in reverse order:

OperatorComp(left, right).inverse == OperatorComp(right.inverse, left.inverse)

range¶

The operator range.

Corresponds to left.range

class odl.operator.operator.OperatorLeftScalarMult(op, scalar)[source]¶

Bases: odl.operator.operator.Operator

Expression type for the operator left scalar multiplication.

OperatorLeftScalarMult(op, scalar) <==> (x –> scalar * op(x))

The scalar multiplication is well-defined only if op.range is a LinearSpace.

derivative(point)[source]¶

Return the derivative at ‘point’.

Left scalar multiplication and derivative are commutative:

OperatorLeftScalarMult(op, scalar).derivative(point) <==> LinearOperatorScalarMult(op.derivative(point), scalar)

LinearOperatorScalarMult

domain¶

The operator domain.

inverse¶

The inverse operator.

The inverse of scalar * op is given by op.inverse * 1/scalar if scalar != 0. If scalar == 0, the inverse is not defined.

OperatorLeftScalarMult(op, scalar).inverse <==> OperatorRightScalarMult(op.inverse, 1.0/scalar)

OperatorRightScalarMult

range¶

The operator range.

class odl.operator.operator.OperatorPointwiseProduct(op1, op2)[source]¶

Bases: odl.operator.operator.Operator

Expression type for the pointwise operator mulitplication.

OperatorPointwiseProduct(op1, op2) <==> (x –> op1(x) * op2(x))

The product is only well-defined for Operator instances where range is an Algebra.

See Operator for a list of public attributes and methods.

domain¶

The operator domain.

range¶

The operator range.

class odl.operator.operator.OperatorRightScalarMult(op, scalar, tmp=None)[source]¶

Bases: odl.operator.operator.Operator

Expression type for the operator right scalar multiplication.

OperatorRightScalarMult(op, scalar) <==> (x –> op(scalar * x))

The scalar multiplication is well-defined only if op.domain is a LinearSpace.

derivative(point)[source]¶

Return the derivative at ‘point’.

The derivative of the right scalar operator multiplication follows the chain rule:

OperatorRightScalarMult(op, scalar).derivative(point) <==> LinearOperatorScalarMult(op.derivative(scalar * point), scalar)

LinearOperatorScalarMult

domain¶

The operator domain.

inverse¶

The inverse operator.

The inverse of op * scalar is given by 1/scalar * op.inverse if scalar != 0. If scalar == 0, the inverse is not defined.

OperatorRightScalarMult(op, scalar).inverse <==> OperatorLeftScalarMult(op.inverse, 1.0/scalar)

OperatorLeftScalarMult

range¶

The operator range.

class odl.operator.operator.OperatorSum(op1, op2, tmp=None)[source]¶

Bases: odl.operator.operator.Operator

Expression type for the sum of operators.

OperatorSum(op1, op2) <==> (x –> op1(x) + op2(x))

The sum is only well-defined for Operator instances where range is a LinearSpace.

See Operator for a list of public attributes and methods.

derivative(point)[source]¶

Return the operator derivative at point.

The derivative of a sum of two operators is equal to the sum of the derivatives.

domain¶

The operator domain.

>>> from odl.space.cartesian import Rn
>>> from odl.operator.default import IdentityOperator
>>> r3 = Rn(3)
>>> op = IdentityOperator(r3)
>>> OperatorSum(op, op).domain
Rn(3)
range¶

The operator range.

>>> from odl.space.cartesian import Rn
>>> from odl.operator.default import IdentityOperator
>>> r3 = Rn(3)
>>> op = IdentityOperator(r3)
>>> OperatorSum(op, op).range
Rn(3)
class odl.operator.operator.SelfAdjointOperator[source]¶

Bases: odl.operator.operator.LinearOperator

Abstract self-adjoint operator.

A self-adjoint operator is a LinearOperator with op.adjoint == op. This implies in particular that op.domain == op.range.

See LinearOperator and Operator for a list of public attributes and methods as well as further help.

adjoint¶

The operator adjoint, equal to the operator itself.

range¶

The operator range, equal to its domain.

odl.operator.operator.linear_operator(call=None, apply=None, inv=None, adj=None, dom=UniversalSet(), ran=UniversalSet())[source]¶

Create a simple linear operator.

Mostly intended for simple prototyping rather than final use.

call : callable
A function taking one argument and returning the result. It will be used for the operator call pattern outp = op(inp).
apply : callable
A function taking two arguments. It will be used for the operator apply pattern op.apply(inp, outp) <==> outp <– op(inp). Return value is assumed to be None and is ignored.
inv : LinearOperator, optional
The operator inverse Default: None
adj : LinearOperator, optional
The operator adjoint Default: None
dom : LinearSpace, optional
The domain of the operator Default: UniversalSet
ran : Set, optional
The range of the operator Default: UniversalSet
op : SimpleLinearOperator
An operator with the provided attributes and methods. SimpleLinearOperator is a subclass of LinearOperator.

It suffices to supply one of the functions call and apply. If dom is a LinearSpace, a default implementation of the respective other method is automatically provided; if not, a NotImplementedError is raised when the other method is called.

See LinearOperator and Operator for a list of public attributes and methods as well as further help.

>>> A = linear_operator(lambda x: 3*x)
>>> A(5)
15
odl.operator.operator.operator(call=None, apply=None, inv=None, deriv=None, dom=UniversalSet(), ran=UniversalSet())[source]¶

Create a simple operator.

Mostly intended for simple prototyping rather than final use.

call : callable
A function taking one argument and returning the result. It will be used for the operator call pattern outp = op(inp).
apply : callable
A function taking two arguments. It will be used for the operator apply pattern op.apply(inp, outp) <==> outp <– op(inp). Return value is assumed to be None and is ignored.
inv : Operator, optional
The operator inverse Default: None
deriv : LinearOperator, optional
The operator derivative Default: None
dom : Set, optional
The domain of the operator Default: UniversalSet
ran : Set, optional
The range of the operator Default: UniversalSet
op : SimpleOperator
An operator with the provided attributes and methods. SimpleOperator is a subclass of Operator.

It suffices to supply one of the functions call and apply. If dom is a LinearSpace, a default implementation of the respective other method is automatically provided; if not, a NotImplementedError is raised when the other method is called.

See Operator for a list of public attributes and methods as well as further help.

>>> A = operator(lambda x: 3*x)
>>> A(5)
15

odl.operator.solvers module¶

General and optimized equation system solvers in linear spaces.

odl.operator.solvers.conjugate_gradient(op, x, rhs, niter=1, partial=None)[source]¶

Optimized version of CGN, uses no temporaries etc.

odl.operator.solvers.exp_zero_seq(scale)[source]¶

The default zero sequence given by: t_m = scale ^ (-m-1)

odl.operator.solvers.gauss_newton(op, x, rhs, niter=1, zero_seq=<generator object exp_zero_seq at 0x0000000008AD0048>, partial=None)[source]¶

Solves op(x) = rhs using the gauss newton method. The inner-solver uses conjugate gradient.

odl.operator.solvers.landweber(op, x, rhs, niter=1, omega=1, partial=None)[source]¶

General and efficient implementation of Landweber iteration

x <- x - omega * (A’)^* (Ax - rhs)

Module contents¶

Core Operator support for ODL.

Operators (module operator)¶

Core operators¶

Name Description
Operator Basic operator class
LinearOperator Basic linear operator class
SelfAdjointOperator Class of linear operators whose adjoint is itself

Operator compositions, sums etc.¶

Name Description
OperatorSum x –> A(x) + B(x)
OperatorComp x –> A(B(x))
OperatorPointwiseProduct x –> A(x) * B(x)
OperatorLeftScalarMult x –> scalar * A(x)
OperatorRightScalarMult x –> A(scalar * x)

Linear Operator compositions, sums etc.¶

Name Description
LinearOperatorSum x –> A(x) + B(x)
LinearOperatorComp x –> A(B(x))
LinearOperatorScalarMult x –> scalar * A(x)

Default (standard) operators (modlule ‘default’)¶

Name Description
ScalingOperator x –> scalar * x
IdentityOperator x –> x

Equation system solvers (module ‘solvers’)¶

Name Description
landweber Landweber’s method
conjugate_gradient Conjugate gradient method for the normal equation
gauss_newton Gauss-Newton method
